ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

EXECUTIVE CONDOMINIUMS
(HDB-type financing for first-time house owners)


    1. Mr Chng Hee Kok asked the Minister for National Development if the Housing and Development Board (HDB) will consider HDB-type financing for executive condominiums for first-time house owners.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Mr Speaker, Sir, Executive Condominiums are introduced to provide Singaporeans private housing at a lower cost. It is therefore appropriate that this form of housing be developed by the private sector. Like other private housing, the sale of Executive Condominiums will be governed by the Housing Developers (Control and Licensing) Act. They are different from HDB Executive Apartments which are governed by the Housing and Development Act. To maintain similar treatment with other private properties, HDB will not be financing the mortgages for Executive Condominiums.

Column: 1510



    The Government will, however, be providing a $40,000 CPF Housing Grant for first-timers to assist them in buying their homes.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok (Tampines GRC): Sir, will the Minister agree that the HDB Executive Condominiums have some special covenants on the first 10 years of its lease? They are therefore not quite like private properties. The second question I would like to ask the Minister is when will the financing schemes be finalised and announced to the public so that those who are on the waiting list of the Executive Apartments can make a decision as to whether they should opt for the Executive Condominiums.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, first, I would like to clarify that these are not HDB Executive Condominiums. These are Executive Condominiums to be built by the private sector.

    Second, the mortgages will be provided by the banks. There will be some covenants which allow the Government to take back the Executive Condominiums if the purchaser violates the condition of staying in it during the first five years or if he violates the condition that the flat can only be sold to Singaporeans and permanent residents in the next five years. Other than that, these flats will be, for all intents and purposes, private properties with strata titles. We will be taking action to amend the Housing Developers (Control and Licensing) Act to take over these Executive Condominiums and the financing arrangements by the banks should be sorted out before the first launch of the Executive Condominiums in June next year.

Column: 1510

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD ESTATES
(Selective En-bloc Redevelopment Scheme)


    2. Mr Chng Hee Kok asked the Minister for National Development whether the Selective En-bloc Redevelopment Scheme is dependent on the level of support in selected estates.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Selective En-bloc Redevelopment Scheme,

Column: 1511

or SERS, is implemented in sites where the current land use is sub-optimal, and the potential for redevelopment is high.

    It is therefore not dependent on the level of support shown but on whether the site itself meets the above criteria as identified by HDB.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok: Sir, going by the reports on Boon Tiong which was selected for this scheme, it seems that the Government is under-selling itself in the process. Some outsiders feel that the scheme is rather generous but the news reports indicate otherwise. Will the Minister like to comment on that, Sir?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: When we redevelop a site under SERS, there are benefits that will be recovered. The redevelopment will provide the country with more units built on the same site. At the same time, we are able to share these benefits with the existing owners of the flats. Let us say, for example, in Boon Tiong, we are able to ensure that the owner of a 4-room flat is not only able to buy a new 4-room flat with 99-year lease, as compared to his present 4-room flat which has got 70-plus years lease, but he also ends up with a cash outlay of $30,000. So from an old flat with 70-odd years lease, he gets a brand new flat with 99 years lease in the same locality and ends up with cash of $30,000 to help him with his renovation. I think that is a fair sharing of benefits and we hope that owners who are affected by SERS will see it in this light and support the scheme.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar GRC): Can I ask the Minister what is the feedback from the three areas where the scheme is to be implemented, namely, Boon Tiong, Toa Payoh and Mountbatten?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, let me explain that Mountbatten is different. In Mountbatten, we are building new flats to encourage existing residents there, who are primarily tenants of rental flats, to buy their flats under the home ownership scheme. So Mountbatten is not under the SERS programme.

Column: 1512



    In Boon Tiong, after the first two dialogue sessions, we have managed to explain the benefits more thoroughly to the residents and we have run an informal survey. Out of the survey returns we have received so far, 75% said that they support the scheme. We are still going door to door to explain the scheme to the individuals because how they respond depend on the individual circumstances. Some want to buy a bigger flat, some want to combine with their children and others want to sell their flats to recoup the monetary benefits. So there are many combinations depending on the individual circumstances. It is better for us to explain the options clearly to the residents so that they can understand the scheme better. But so far, the informal survey in Boon Tiong shows that 75% are keen to participate in the scheme. Meanwhile, we are still conducting the door-to-door explanation of the scheme to the Boon Tiong residents.

    In Toa Payoh, Mr Dhanabalan had two dialogue sessions with the residents affected. The feedback so far has been very encouraging. All the residents are happy to be given this opportunity to join in the SERS scheme. The singles who bought 3-room flats in Toa Payoh are a little disappointed. Although they can buy a 4-room flat in the new development they are not given the $30,000 discount. We have to explain to the singles that this is a fair sharing of benefits that a family who buys a new flat enjoys a $30,000 discount but a single is allowed to buy a 4-room flat, so the benefits should be less than that enjoyed by a family. With that explanation, Mr Dhanabalan is still proceeding on a door-to-door basis to explain to the various residents. Depending on the individual circumstances, he is confident that the residents affected in Toa Payoh are fully in support of the programme.

     Mr Ling How Doong (Bukit Gombak): Is it true that in Boon Tiong Road, the land acquired will ultimately be sold to private developers?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: It all depends on the circumstances. In the case of Boon Tiong

Column: 1513

specifically, we have explained the redevelopment programme. In Boon Tiong, we will sequentially rebuild the site for HDB flats. But this does not preclude other areas where, having built enough flats to rehouse the existing residents and if there is land left over, there is no reason why we should not consider either building HDB flats or tender it out for private housing. But our undertaking to the residents there under the SERS scheme is that we understand their wishes to continue living in the area and we would try to build enough flats to meet their needs. Once that is met, then it does not make very much difference whether we continue to build more HDB flats or we sell the land for private housing. The net result is we get more flats in the very prime and very attractive areas for all Singaporeans.

     Mr Ling How Doong: Does the Minister not think that if the intention of the Government to acquire the property is to ultimately dispose it to the private developers, then the compensation should be more than what it is paying them now?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: It does not necessarily follow because when we sell a piece of land to private developers and the density is lower, in fact, the net return is sometimes lower than if we had built HDB flats where we can build to a higher density. The net proceeds of the land sale could be higher under the HDB programme or it could be lower under the private housing programme. It depends on the density and location.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok: Will the Minister confirm that not all the land in HDB estates belong to the residents? They only have a right to use the land.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Now we are getting into the nitty-gritty. For example, in Boon Tiong, there is a misconception that there is a lot of money to be made when Government acquires the flats and redevelop the site. As we had tried to explain to the residents of Boon Tiong, if they look at the redevelopment of the site, the first redevelopment is on an old school. That is state land. That land does not belong

Column: 1514

to the HDB residents. To start the programme, we have to build flats to rehouse them. The first lot of flats are built on current state land.

    Secondly, there is another strip of vacant land between the Boon Tiong blocks of flats and the Bukit Ho Swee blocks of flats. That is currently state land. We could have gone in and build more HDB flats. When they read the newspaper report that there is a net increase of so many units, they were under the impression that this arose out of the redevelopment of their sites and we had to explain to them that this was not so. In fact, the net increase includes sites which are currently state land, the old school as well as the vacant land north of the existing site.

    Mr Chng Hee Kok's point that the residents do not own the land is a legal point, ie, right now the common properties are still the properties of HDB. So the residents only have ownership of the title to the units which they live in, but not the common property. That is why it is not possible for us to let the residents negotiate with the private developer to redevelop the site. The land technically still belongs to HDB. But we are not pursuing that technical and legal point. Basically, we want to tell residents affected by SERS that there are redevelopment benefits that accrue to the country at large. At the same time, to be fair, we have designed a package in which they share in the redevelopment benefits. The simple way to look at the sharing of the redevelopment benefits is if you own a old 4-room flat today, under SERS, you will get a brand new 4-room flat with 99 years lease plus $30,000 cash. That I think is a fair compensation.

     Dr Vasoo: Sir, what steps would the Ministry be taking to help older senior citizens who have very little savings to take advantage of the scheme?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Again, there is this myth of older Singaporeans who cannot take advantage of this scheme and would be left out. Let me assure Members that older Singaporeans are as shrewd as younger Singaporeans and they know

Column: 1515

how to benefit from the scheme by combining with their children to buy the biggest flat available. There is a danger here - I must explain to the House - when we carried out the surveys we asked each and every resident what type of flat they hoped to purchase in the end. If they indicate that they cannot afford it and they only want to buy a 4-room flat, then we will build more 4-room flats than 5-room flats. But in the end, you may find that the 5-room flats give them more returns than a 4-room flat. And if they do not fill up the survey form accurately, they may find that there are not enough 5-room flats to go round. So there is this myth that senior citizens may not be able to afford it. Many of them are, in fact, planning to combine with their children to buy a bigger flat. They have lived with their children in the housing estate in which their children have grown up. This is a development that we would like to encourage. I am confident that when the project is completed, they will find that it is a worthwhile project for them to participate in.

     Dr Vasoo: Sir, if there are cases of senior citizens who really cannot afford it, are there any plans to help them to remain within the area?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: If indeed a senior citizen says that he cannot afford to buy a new flat, HDB will help him buy a 3-room flat in the same vicinity and let him enjoy some of the monetary benefits of selling the rights to a new flat in that area. So we assure all senior citizens that if they just want to continue living in a 3-room flat in the same area, they will still end up with a net cash surplus, and HDB will help them buy another 3-room flat in the area. So there is no problem. But if they say that they cannot afford to buy a 5-room flat, then there is a problem. But if they say, "Look, I am staying in a 3-room flat today, and I am prepared to stay in another 3-room flat in the same vicinity.", HDB is prepared to help them buy a 3-room flat from the resale market. I can assure Members that by selling off the benefits of a brand new flat in the same area, they will still end up with a cash surplus.

Column: 1516

CENTRAL PROVIDENT FUND ACT
(Amendment to incorporate minimum protection to spouses)


    3. Mr Chng Hee Kok asked the Minister for Labour, in view of recent court rulings on the division of Central Provident Fund (CPF) savings upon divorce, if he will consider introducing legislation to amend the CPF Act so as to incorporate minimum protection to spouses of CPF contributors irrespective of the contributors' nominations.

     The Minister for Labour (Dr Lee Boon Yang): Mr Speaker, Sir, at present, a CPF member may nominate any person to be the beneficiary of his CPF savings upon death. If there is no nomination, upon death, his CPF savings will be distributed by the Public Trustee to the spouse, children and other family members according to existing law.

    The current nomination rule also provides that a nomination is automatically revoked by marriage. The intention of this is to force CPF members to re-consider their nominations in favour of their spouses or other members of their families. If the member fails to re-nominate, his CPF savings will be distributed as though there is no nomination.

    If we amend the Act to incorporate a minimum protection to the spouse of a CPF member by providing in law that the spouse is entitled to a portion of his CPF savings, it would erode the right of CPF members to nominate person or persons of their choice to receive their CPF savings.

    Sir, in 1978, an amendment similar to the Member's proposal was, in fact, incorporated in a CPF (Amendment) Bill which was subsequently referred to a Select Committee. The Select Committee received various representations from organisations and persons arguing that it was undesirable to overrule a CPF member's nomination for beneficiaries of his CPF savings. The proposal was subsequently not taken up.

    In view of the above, my Ministry will not amend the CPF Act as suggested by the Member.

Column: 1517



     Mr Chng Hee Kok: Mr Speaker, Sir, as the promotion of family values is the cornerstone of our society's philosophy, will the Minister say that, hypothetically, it is against the country's interest should a CPF member nominate a person other than his family members, for example, he nominates his pet dog as his beneficiary under the CPF scheme that we have currently?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, currently, about 50% of the CPF members do not or fail to make nominations after their marriage. In other words, should anyone from this 50% pass away before the age of 55, the CPF savings will be transferred to the Public Trustee who will then distribute it according to the intestate law. In which case, the interest of the spouse, the children or immediate family members will be looked after because the intestate law spells out clearly how it should be distributed. Out of the remaining 50% who have nominated, about 95% of them nominate their immediate family members as beneficiary. Sir, therefore there is no widespread abuse of privilege to nominate beneficiaries to their CPF savings. I think, by and large, CPF members are very concerned and sensible about how their CPF savings should be distributed upon their death. And I do not see any reason why we should now remove this power to nominate beneficiary to a member's CPF savings.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok: Sir, I recognise that there is still the 5% which the Minister has mentioned. How is he going to protect the interest of the spouses? Usually, these are cases whereby the surviving members of the family have no legal recourse or they may come from the lower-income group and unable to seek legal recourse.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, among the small percentage of CPF members who have nominated beneficiaries who are not members of their immediate family, they have, in fact, nominated their relatives, ie, their uncle, aunty or nephew, to be their beneficiaries. They may have special reasons for doing so, and I do not think we should override their personal preference in such matter.

Column: 1518



     Dr Kanwaljit Soin (Nominated Member): Sir, would the Minister please tell the House whether the statutory right of nomination takes precedence over the High Court's ruling because CPF monies are now considered part of matrimonial assets, and if the nomination is not in line with the division as suggested by the High Court, would the statutory right of nomination take precedence?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, I believe the Member's supplementary question has overlapped into the question that she herself has asked. With your permission, Sir, could I proceed to answer that question first?

     Mr Speaker: All right.

CENTRAL PROVIDENT FUND ACT
(Amendment to disburse portion of money to spouse as part of divorce settlement)


    4. Dr Kanwaljit Soin asked the Minister for Labour if he will consider introducing legislation to amend the Central Provident Fund Act so that it is in line with the recent Appeal Court's ruling that a portion of a person's CPF money can be ordered to be held for disbursement to the other spouse as part of a divorce settlement.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Sir, the Appeal Court's Judgement was made in connection with the appeal by CPF Board on a divorce petition. The Appeal Court ruled that the CPF Act does not prevent a spouse, upon dissolution of marriage, to have a proprietary interest in such portion of the other spouse's CPF savings as the Court may order. It also ruled that the proprietary interest does not constitute a form of attachment, sequestration or levy on the CPF savings prohibited by section 25 of the CPF Act.

    The Appeal Court also affirmed that it can partition a portion of the CPF savings of a member and order a charge on that portion for the purpose of payment to the ex-spouse when the CPF member reaches the CPF withdrawal age.

    In addition, the Court of Appeal ruled that the current CPF Act does not prevent

Column: 1519
